content.text: The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L\) is 0.0N
The student measures the length \(l_0\) of the spring. She records \(l_0 = 16 \text{mm}\) in Table 1.1
Draw a diagram of the spring to show clearly the length \(l_0\) of the spring
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring for each load using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\)
Record the values of \(e\) in Table 1.1
Complete the column headings in Table 1.1
The student suspends a load \(L = 0.20 \text{N}\) from the spring. She records the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1
She repeats the procedure using loads \(L = 0.40 \text{N}\), \(0.60 \text{N}\), \(0.80 \text{N}\) and \(1.00 \text{N}\). The readings are shown in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(L\) (y-axis) against \(e\) (x-axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Use the graph to determine \(\mathsf{e}_{\mathrm{A}}\), the extension produced by a load of \(0.50\mathrm{N}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
eA =
A student investigates the stretching of a spring
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Write the times in the first column of Table 2.1
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker. He places a lid on the beaker. He places the thermometer in the hot water in the beaker
He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). He immediately starts a stop-watch
He continues recording the temperature in Table 2.1 at 30 s intervals until he has seven sets of readings
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta =\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water using the equation \(R = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}\), where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
A student states that the water cools slowly

Suggest **two** changes to the experiment that the student makes to increase the rate of cooling of the hot water without changing the starting temperature of the hot water. Room temperature remains constant
State one precaution that you would take to obtain accurate temperature readings
Explain briefly the reason for this precaution
statement
explanation
The student uses a measuring cylinder to measure \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of water. He takes the reading from the bottom of the meniscus
Explain the reason for taking the reading at the bottom of the meniscus rather than at the top of the meniscus
A student investigates the cooling of water
Fig. 2.1 shows the set-up
• Draw a normal **NL** through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block
• Label the normal **NL**
• Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal **NL** crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{DC}\), below line \(\mathbf{PC}\), at an angle \(i = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal
• Mark with neat crosses (X) the positions for two pins on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment
• Label the positions \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{EC}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
\(\theta =\)
The student looks from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block
She adjusts her line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

She places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown in Fig. 3.1
State one precaution that the student takes to produce an accurate ray trace
She replaces pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) in the same positions used in (a)(iii)

She observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the curved side of the block. She adjusts her line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

She places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_5\), \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) are shown on Fig. 3.2
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{C}\)
Label \(\mathbf{G}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between the line \(\mathbf{AB}\) and the line \(\mathbf{GC}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
Calculate the angle \(\beta\) between the line \(\mathbf{GC}\) and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
The student replaces the transparent block on the ray-trace sheet in the position shown in Fig. 3.2
A student suggests that angle \(\beta\) should be equal to the angle of incidence \(i = 20^{\circ}\)
State whether your result supports the suggestion and justify your answer
statement
justification
A student investigates the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block
Fig. 3.1 shows her ray-trace sheet
Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the change in current in a conducting liquid as the distance between two electrodes is changed. The circuit is shown in Fig. 4.1
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in current in the liquid as the distance between the electrodes is changed
You should:
· explain briefly how to do the investigation
· state the key variables to keep constant
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion
